summary_variants.short_answer: Jane Goodall is a British primatologist whose long-term field studies of wild chimpanzees reshaped our understanding of animal behavior.
summary_variants.kid_friendly: Jane Goodall watched chimpanzees in the forest for many years and learned they can make tools and have families like we do.
summary_variants.standard: Jane Goodall (born 1934) is a British primatologist and conservation advocate best known for her six-decade study of wild chimpanzees in Gombe Stream National Park, Tanzania. Her observations of tool use, social bonds, and emotions in chimpanzees transformed primatology and fueled global conservation work.
summary_variants.expert_notes: Note 1960 Gombe arrival, National Geographic funding, findings on tool modification, political dynamics within chimp communities, and global Roots & Shoots outreach.

notable_actions: Documented tool use among chimpanzees at Gombe
Advocated for habitat conservation and animal welfare
